content.question: The random variable <math alttext="W" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>W</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> can take on the values of 0, 1, 2, 3, or 4. The expected value of <math alttext="W" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>W</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is 2.8. Which of the following is the best interpretation of the expected value of random variable <math alttext="W" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>W</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> ?

choices.label: A randomly selected value of <math alttext="W" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>W</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> must be equal to 2.8.
The values of <math alttext="W" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>W</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> vary by about 2.8 units from the mean of the distribution.
The mean of a random sample of values selected from the distribution will be 2.8.
A value of <math alttext="W" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>W</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> randomly selected from the distribution will be less than 2.8 units of the mean.

For values of <math alttext="W" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>W</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> repeatedly selected at random from the distribution, the mean of the selected values will approach 2.8.

content.answer: For values of <math alttext="W" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>W</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> repeatedly selected at random from the distribution, the mean of the selected values will approach 2.8.

unit.text: 4: Probability, Random Variables, and Probability Distributions

topic.text: 4.8: Mean and Standard Deviation of Random Variables

skill.text: Skill 4.B: Interpret statistical calculations and findings to assign meaning or assess a claim.
